title: Ajay Devgn
text:
Vishal Veeru Devgan (born 2 April 1969), known professionally as Ajay Devgn, is an Indian actor, film director and producer. He has appeared in over a <a href="Ajay%20Devgan%20filmography">hundred Hindi films</a>. Devgn has won <a href="List%20of%20awards%20and%20nominations%20received%20by%20Ajay%20Devgn">numerous accolades</a>, including two <a href="National%20Film%20Awards">National Film Awards</a> and four <a href="Filmfare%20Awards">Filmfare Awards</a>. In 2016, he was honoured by the <a href="Government%20of%20India">Government of India</a> with the <a href="Padma%20Shri">Padma Shri</a>, the fourth-highest <a href="Indian%20honours%20system">civilian honour</a> of the country.
Devgn began his professional career with "<a href="Phool%20Aur%20Kaante">Phool Aur Kaante</a>" in 1991. He then rose to prominence as an action hero starring in successful films such as "<a href="Jigar">Jigar</a>" (1992), "<a href="Sangram%20%281993%20film%29">Sangram</a>" (1993), "<a href="Dilwale%20%281994%20film%29">Dilwale</a>" (1994), and "<a href="Diljale">Diljale</a>" (1996). He went on to give critically acclaimed performances in "<a href="Zakhm">Zakhm</a>" (1998), "<a href="Hum%20Dil%20De%20Chuke%20Sanam">Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam</a>" (1999), "<a href="Company%20%282002%20film%29">Company</a>" (2002), "<a href="Deewangee">Deewangee</a>" (2002), and "<a href="The%20Legend%20of%20Bhagat%20Singh">The Legend of Bhagat Singh</a>" (2002). After the success of ' (2006), he went on to collaborate with <a href="Rohit%20Shetty">Rohit Shetty</a> on a number of action-comedies including "<a href="Golmaal%20Returns">Golmaal Returns</a>" (2008), ' (2009), "<a href="Golmaal%203">Golmaal 3</a>" (2010), "<a href="Singham">Singham</a>" (2011), "<a href="Bol%20Bachchan">Bol Bachchan</a>" (2012), "<a href="Singham%20Returns">Singham Returns</a>" (2014), and "<a href="Golmaal%20Again">Golmaal Again</a>" (2017). His highest grossing movies include "<a href="Total%20Dhamaal">Total Dhamaal</a>" (2019) "<a href="Tanhaji">Tanhaji</a>" (2020).
In addition, Devgn owns a production company <a href="Ajay%20Devgn%20FFilms">Ajay Devgn FFilms</a>, which was established in 2000. In 2008, he debuted as a film director with "<a href="U%20Me%20Aur%20Hum">U Me Aur Hum</a>". He has been married to film actress <a href="Kajol">Kajol</a> since 1999.
Family background and marriage.
Devgan was born to a <a href="Punjabi%20Hindu">Punjabi Hindu</a> family originally from <a href="Amritsar">Amritsar</a> (<a href="Punjab%2C%20India">Punjab</a>). The family has connections to the <a href="Hindi%20film%20industry">Hindi film industry</a> in <a href="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>. Devgn's father, <a href="Veeru%20Devgan">Veeru Devgan</a>, was a stunt choreographer and action-film director and his mother, Veena, is a film producer. His brother, <a href="Anil%20Devgan">Anil Devgan</a>, is a filmmaker and screenwriter. Devgn graduated from the Silver Beach High School in <a href="Juhu">Juhu</a> and then studied at <a href="Mithibai%20College">Mithibai College</a>.
Devgn began a relationship with the actress <a href="Karisma%20Kapoor">Karisma Kapoor</a> while filming "Jigar", however, the couple ended their relationship in 1995. That same year, Devgn's relationship with the actress, <a href="Kajol%20Mukherjee">Kajol Mukherjee</a>, began whilst they were co-starring in "Gundaraj". The media called them "an unlikely pair" due to their contrasting personalities. On 24 February 1999, the couple married in a traditional Maharashtrian <a href="Hindu%20wedding">Hindu ceremony</a> at the Devgan home. The couple has two children. Their daughter, Nysa, was born in 2003 and their son, Yug, was born in 2010. Devgn and Kajol stored their newborn son's umbilical cord blood and tissues to act as a source of stem cells in case of serious ailment. In August 2009, Devgn changed the spelling of his surname <a href="Devgan">Devgan</a> to "Devgn", at the request of his family. He is a practicing <a href="Shaivism">Shaiva</a> <a href="Hindu">Hindu</a> who prominently wears a <a href="Rudraksha">Rudraksha</a> which, along with other religious themes, features in his films. Devgn was the first <a href="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> personality to own a private jet for transport to shooting locations, to promotions and for personal trips.
Career.
Film debut, breakthrough and rise to prominence (1991–99).
As Devgn entered the film industry in 1991, he changed his stage name from his birth name, Vishal, to "Ajay" due to several other actors named Vishal being launched at the same time, including <a href="Manoj%20Kumar">Manoj Kumar</a>'s son. He began his professional career in "<a href="Phool%20Aur%20Kaante">Phool Aur Kaante</a>" and received a <a href="Filmfare%20Award%20for%20Best%20Male%20Debut">Filmfare Award for Best Male Debut</a>. He co-starred with <a href="Madhoo">Madhoo</a>. In his opening scene, Devgn performed a <a href="Split%20%28gymnastics%29">split</a> while balancing between two motorcycles. His next film was "<a href="Jigar">Jigar</a>" (1992), a Bollywood <a href="martial%20arts%20film">martial arts film</a> co-starring <a href="Karisma%20Kapoor">Karisma Kapoor</a>. It was released on <a href="Diwali">Diwali</a> weekend and became the seventh-highest-grossing movie of that year, taking at the <a href="box%20office">box office</a>.
In 1993, Devgn starred in "<a href="Dil%20Hai%20Betaab">Dil Hai Betaab</a>", a movie about a love triangle and romantic themes such as revenge. He next featured in "<a href="Divya%20Shakti">Divya Shakti</a>" and then "<a href="Sangram%20%281993%20film%29">Sangram</a>", a story of enmity between two fathers. Devgan then worked with <a href="Deepak%20Bahry">Deepak Bahry</a>, who directed the action film "<a href="Ek%20Hi%20Raasta%20%281993%20film%29">Ek Hi Raasta</a>", and with Deepak Pawar, who directed "<a href="Platform%20%281993%20film%29">Platform</a>". Other releases that year were "<a href="Shaktiman%20%281993%20film%29">Shaktiman</a>", "<a href="Dhanwan%20%281993%20film%29">Dhanwan</a>" and "Bedardi".
In 1994, Devgn starred in <a href="Harry%20Baweja">Harry Baweja</a>'s romantic action film "<a href="Dilwale%20%281994%20film%29">Dilwale</a>". He played the part of Arun Saxena, a man with intellectual impairment. The movie was the tenth-highest-grossing movie of the year. His next release was "<a href="Kanoon">Kanoon</a>" and then Kuku Kohli's "<a href="Suhaag%20%281994%20film%29">Suhaag</a>" with Akshay Kumar. The movie was about two friends. Devgn played Ajay Sharma/Malhotra. "Suhaag" was the seventh-highest-grossing movie of the year. His next film was "<a href="Vijaypath">Vijaypath</a>". Shooting dates for "Vijaypath" clashed with those of "<a href="Karan%20Arjun">Karan Arjun</a>" which Devgn declined. "Vijaypath" was the eighth-highest-grossing film of the year.
In 1995, Devgn appeared in <a href="Mahesh%20Bhatt">Mahesh Bhatt</a>'s movie "<a href="Naajayaz">Naajayaz</a>" and then "<a href="Hulchul%20%281995%20film%29">Hulchul</a>" directed by Milan Luthria. Kajol co-starred. Devgn and Kajol then appeared in "<a href="Gundaraj">Gundaraj</a>" which did not perform well at the box office. His next release was "<a href="Haqeeqat%20%281995%20film%29">Haqeeqat</a>" costarring with Tabu. This film was the eleventh-highest-grossing movie of the year.
In 1996, Devgn starred in the action movie "<a href="Jung%20%281996%20film%29">Jung</a>" with Mithun Chakraborty, <a href="Rambha%20%28actress%29">Rambha</a> and <a href="Aditya%20Pancholi">Aditya Pancholi</a>. His next release was an action movie called "<a href="Jaan%20%28film%29">Jaan</a>", with Twinkle Khanna. He then starred in <a href="Harry%20Baweja">Harry Baweja</a>'s film "<a href="Diljale">Diljale</a>", where he played a terrorist character called Shaka.
In 1997, Devgn starred in a poorly received movie, "<a href="Itihaas%20%281997%20film%29">Itihaas</a>", with Twinkle Khanna. His next release was <a href="Indra%20Kumar">Indra Kumar</a>'s romantic comedy "<a href="Ishq%20%281997%20film%29">Ishq</a>" with <a href="Aamir%20Khan">Aamir Khan</a>, <a href="Juhi%20Chawla">Juhi Chawla</a> and <a href="Kajol">Kajol</a>. In this successful film, Devgn played Ajay, a rich boy in love with a poor girl, (Kajol). The film grossed . The film was the fourth-highest-grossing film of the year.
In 1998, Devgn gave a critically acclaimed performance in <a href="Mahesh%20Bhatt">Mahesh Bhatt</a>'s drama, "<a href="Zakhm">Zakhm</a>", and received his first <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor">National Film Award for Best Actor</a>. In 1999, in "<a href="Hum%20Dil%20De%20Chuke%20Sanam">Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam</a>", Devgn played Vanraj, a man who tries to unite his wife with her lover. Devgn then starred in "<a href="Major%20Saab">Major Saab</a>" with <a href="Amitabh%20Bachchan">Amitabh Bachchan</a> and <a href="Sonali%20Bendre">Sonali Bendre</a> where he played the character of an army officer. The movie was successful and was the tenth-highest-grossing film of the year. He next starred with Kajol in <a href="Anees%20Bazmee">Anees Bazmee</a>'s second film, the romantic comedy "<a href="Pyaar%20To%20Hona%20Hi%20Tha">Pyaar To Hona Hi Tha</a>", a remake of the 1995 American film "<a href="French%20Kiss%20%281995%20film%29">French Kiss</a>". It grossed <a href="Indian%20rupee">Indian rupee</a>s. Devgn's next release was <a href="Mahesh%20Bhatt">Mahesh Bhatt</a>'s "<a href="Zakhm">Zakhm</a>". The plot examines communal tension in Mumbai during riots. Devgn played a man who is fed up with religious conflict. Devgn won several awards for his performance, including the <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor">National Film Award for Best Actor</a> and the <a href="Star%20Screen%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor">Star Screen Award for Best Actor</a>.
In 1999, Devgn starred in the romantic drama "<a href="Hum%20Dil%20De%20Chuke%20Sanam">Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam</a>", in which he played Vanraj, a man who tries to help his wife (<a href="Aishwarya%20Rai">Aishwarya Rai</a>) reunite with her lover (<a href="Salman%20Khan">Salman Khan</a>). <a href="Hum%20Dil%20De%20Chuke%20Sanam">Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam</a> marked a significant turning point in Devgan's career. The film, an adaptation of <a href="Maitreyi%20Devi">Maitreyi Devi</a>'s Bengali novel "<a href="Na%20Hanyate">Na Hanyate</a>", was directed by <a href="Sanjay%20Leela%20Bhansali">Sanjay Leela Bhansali</a> and co-starred <a href="Salman%20Khan">Salman Khan</a> and <a href="Aishwarya%20Rai">Aishwarya Rai</a>. Devgn was highly praised for his performance. Rediff said: "Ajay's role reminds you of one he did in another film, "Pyaar Toh Hona Hi Tha". There he is searching for the boyfriend of the girl he secretly loves. But intense scenes are his forte and he does well here. He's particularly good in the scene where he gets exasperated with his wife's stubbornness and strives to keep his cool." The movie was successful and Devgan was nominated for the Filmfare best actor award. After that, he appeared in "<a href="Hindustan%20Ki%20Kasam">Hindustan Ki Kasam</a>" with Amitabh Bachchan and Sonali Bendre. He then worked with the director Milan Luthria in "<a href="Kachche%20Dhaage">Kachche Dhaage</a>", with Saif Ali Khan and Manisha Koirala. The movie was a box-office hit. He then performed in the successful movie "<a href="Hogi%20Pyaar%20Ki%20Jeet">Hogi Pyaar Ki Jeet</a>", a romantic comedy, and then in his home production movie with Kajol, and director, Prakash Jha. The film was titled "<a href="Dil%20Kya%20Kare">Dil Kya Kare</a>". His other movies in 1999 were "<a href="Gair%20%28film%29">Gair</a>" and "<a href="Thakshak">Thakshak</a>" in which he played a strong, silent man.
Critical acclaim and awards success (2000–09).
In 2000, Devgn performed in <a href="Harry%20Baweja">Harry Baweja</a>'s "<a href="Deewane">Deewane</a>". The film did not do well at the box office. In the same year, Devgn starred in his first home production; "<a href="Raju%20Chacha">Raju Chacha</a>", with Kajol. The film was moderately successful.
In 2001, Devgn starred in another moderately successful film; "<a href="Yeh%20Raaste%20Hain%20Pyaar%20Ke">Yeh Raaste Hain Pyaar Ke</a>" with <a href="Madhuri%20Dixit">Madhuri Dixit</a> and <a href="Preity%20Zinta">Preity Zinta</a>. His next release was "<a href="Lajja%20%282001%20film%29">Lajja</a>", with <a href="Manisha%20Koirala">Manisha Koirala</a>, <a href="Madhuri%20Dixit">Madhuri Dixit</a>, <a href="Jackie%20Shroff">Jackie Shroff</a> and <a href="Anil%20Kapoor">Anil Kapoor</a>. He was nominated for the <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Supporting%20Actor%20Award">Filmfare Best Supporting Actor Award</a>. However, the film was not popular with the public. <a href="Mahesh%20Manjrekar">Mahesh Manjrekar</a>'s "<a href="Tera%20Mera%20Saath%20Rahen">Tera Mera Saath Rahen</a>" followed.
In 2002, Devgn performed in <a href="Ram%20Gopal%20Varma">Ram Gopal Varma</a>'s fictional examination of the <a href="Mumbai%20underworld">Mumbai underworld</a> in the film "<a href="Company%20%282002%20film%29">Company</a>". Devgn played a gangster named Malik. Both "Company" and Devgn's performance received critical acclaim. As <a href="Taran%20Adarsh">Taran Adarsh</a> reviewed: "Ajay Devgn enacts his role to perfection. A controlled performance, the actor takes to this complex character like a fish takes to water. He underplays his part with admirable ease." Devgan was nominated for the <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Actor%20Award">Filmfare Best Actor Award</a> and won the <a href="Filmfare%20Critics%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor">Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor</a>. Devgn's next release was <a href="David%20Dhawan">David Dhawan</a>'s comedy "<a href="Hum%20Kisise%20Kum%20Nahin">Hum Kisise Kum Nahin</a>", with <a href="Amitabh%20Bachchan">Amitabh Bachchan</a>, <a href="Sanjay%20Dutt">Sanjay Dutt</a> and <a href="Aishwarya%20Rai">Aishwarya Rai</a>. The same year, he played the role of <a href="Bhagat%20Singh">Bhagat Singh</a>, in <a href="Rajkumar%20Santoshi">Rajkumar Santoshi</a>'s biopic "<a href="The%20Legend%20of%20Bhagat%20Singh">The Legend of Bhagat Singh</a>". His performance was well received by critics. Taran Adarsh said, "Ajay Devgn has lived the role. To state that he is excellent would be an understatement. His performance is bound to win admiration from cinegoers, besides fetching awards." The film was released on 7 June 2002 and went on to win two <a href="National%20Film%20Awards">National Film Awards</a>, including the <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Feature%20Film%20in%20Hindi">National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Hindi</a>, and three <a href="Filmfare%20Awards">Filmfare Awards</a>, including the <a href="Filmfare%20Critics%20Award%20for%20Best%20Movie">Filmfare Critics Award for Best Movie</a>. Despite these awards, and Devgn winning his second <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor">National Film Award for Best Actor</a> for his performance, the film was not popular with the public. Devgn went on to perform in <a href="Anees%20Bazmee">Anees Bazmee</a>'s "<a href="Deewangee">Deewangee</a>". The film was partially inspired by <a href="William%20Diehl">William Diehl</a>'s novel, "<a href="Primal%20Fear%20%28novel%29">Primal Fear</a>". The film earned Devgn several awards for his role including a <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Villain%20Award">Filmfare Best Villain Award</a>, the <a href="Star%20Screen%20Award%20for%20Best%20Villain">Star Screen Award for Best Villain</a> and the <a href="Zee%20Cine%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor%20in%20a%20Negative%20Role">Zee Cine Award for Best Actor in a Negative Role</a>. The film was a success at the box office.
In 2003, Devgn starred in Ram Gopal Verma's horror film "<a href="Bhoot%20%28film%29">Bhoot</a>", opposite <a href="Urmila%20Matondkar">Urmila Matondkar</a>. The film was appreciated critically and performed well at the box office. He then starred in the action thriller "" with the actress debutante, <a href="Neha%20Dhupia">Neha Dhupia</a>. The film was a commercial success. Devgn next performed in <a href="Milan%20Luthria">Milan Luthria</a>'s romantic film "<a href="Chori%20Chori">Chori Chori</a>", opposite <a href="Rani%20Mukherji">Rani Mukherji</a> and <a href="Sonali%20Bendre">Sonali Bendre</a>. This film did not succeed at the box office.
Devgn's next release of the year was <a href="Prakash%20Jha">Prakash Jha</a>'s "<a href="Gangaajal">Gangaajal</a>". The film was set in the time of the <a href="1980%20Bhagalpur%20blindings">blinding incident</a> in <a href="Bhagalpur">Bhagalpur</a>, Bihar. Rediff.com said, "Ajay Devgan pulls up an ace with a part tailormade to reinforce his seething-under-the-surface angry hero image. To his credit (and the director's), he brings style and grace to a largely stereotypical, righteous protagonist. To a great extent, his presence covers up the film's patchiness in the second half." Devgn was nominated for the <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Actor%20Award">Filmfare Best Actor Award</a> for this performance. He then worked in <a href="Rohit%20Shetty">Rohit Shetty</a>'s directional debut "<a href="Zameen%20%282003%20film%29">Zameen</a>" and <a href="J.%20P.%20Dutta">J. P. Dutta</a>'s war film "<a href="LOC%20Kargil">LOC Kargil</a>".
In 2004, Devgn was cast with <a href="Amitabh%20Bachchan">Amitabh Bachchan</a>, <a href="Aishwarya%20Rai">Aishwarya Rai</a> and <a href="Akshay%20Kumar">Akshay Kumar</a> in <a href="Rajkumar%20Santoshi">Rajkumar Santoshi</a>'s action thriller "<a href="Khakee">Khakee</a>". The film was released on 23 January 2004. It received positive reviews and became one of the highest-grossing films of 2004. In "Khakee", Devgn once again played a villain. His performance as a police officer turned murderer was well received by critics. Taran Adarsh said: "Ajay Devgan adds yet another feather in his cap with a performance that could've been played only by a master performer. His confrontations with Amitabh Bachchan are exemplary." Later in 2004, Devgn appeared in <a href="Indra%20Kumar">Indra Kumar</a>'s "". He also starred in "<a href="Yuva">Yuva</a>".
Devgn next collaborated with <a href="Rituparno%20Ghosh">Rituparno Ghosh</a> in the relationship drama "<a href="Raincoat%20%28film%29">Raincoat</a>", with Aishwaraya Rai. The film is an adaptation of <a href="O.%20Henry">O. Henry</a>'s "<a href="The%20Gift%20of%20the%20Magi">The Gift of the Magi</a>". "Raincoat" met with wide critical acclaim and won the <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Feature%20Film%20in%20Hindi">National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Hindi</a>. Devgn was praised for his performance. Rediff said: "Hesitation, desperation, humiliation – Ajay Devgn conveys them eloquently. His Manoj is no cool dude, but just another lower middle-class guy in misery, with whom none would like to switch place. He particularly stands out in the scenes where he cries in the bathroom, or begs Neeru not to marry someone else." In 2004, Devgn was also seen in a cameo appearance in "".
2005 was a less successful year for Devgn. His movies were not financially successful. They included "<a href="Insan">Insan</a>", "<a href="Blackmail%20%282005%20film%29">Blackmail</a>", "<a href="Main%20Aisa%20Hi%20Hoon">Main Aisa Hi Hoon</a>", "<a href="Tango%20Charlie">Tango Charlie</a>" and "<a href="Shikhar%20%28film%29">Shikhar</a>". However, the films "<a href="Kaal">Kaal</a>" and "<a href="Apaharan">Apaharan</a>" did well. For his performance in "Apaharan", Devgn was nominated for the <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor">National Film Award for Best Actor</a> and the <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Actor%20Award">Filmfare Best Actor Award</a>. His performance as a villain in "Kaal" also earned him a nomination for the <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Villain%20Award">Filmfare Best Villain Award</a>.
In 2006 Devgn played <a href="Othello">Othello</a> in "<a href="Omkara%20%282006%20film%29">Omkara</a>", an Hindi adaptation of <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>'s "<a href="Othello">Othello</a>". It was directed by <a href="Vishal%20Bhardwaj">Vishal Bhardwaj</a>. The film is a tragedy of sexual jealousy set against the backdrop of the political system in <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>. It premiered at the <a href="2006%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">2006 Cannes Film Festival</a> and was screened at the <a href="Cairo%20International%20Film%20Festival">Cairo International Film Festival</a>. "Omkara" was well received by critics. Rediff said: "Othello is a tricky role, a leading man eclipsed by the villain. Yet the Moor is a brooding and compelling character, and Ajay Devgn does valiantly with his material. Omkara strips Othello of the racism, exchanging his black skin for surprisingly inconsequential half-Brahminism. Ajay's best bits are when restrained, and while there is a bit of a seen-that feel to his character, by the time the film is over, you realise just how unflinchingly solid he's been." Taran Adarsh said: "Ajay makes a stirring and powerful interpretation of a man haunted by uncertainty about his lover's faithfulness. The serious look that Ajay carries suits him to the T. Of course, Ajay is exceptional in the film and looks every inch the character he portrays."
In 2006, Devgn also starred in <a href="Rohit%20Shetty">Rohit Shetty</a>'s "<a href="Golmaal%20%282006%20film%29">Golmaal</a>". It had two sequels "<a href="Golmaal%20Returns">Golmaal Returns</a>" and "<a href="Golmaal%203">Golmaal 3</a>". In the same year, Devgn was featured in a short documentary about the <a href="Mumbai%20floods%20of%202005">Mumbai floods of 2005</a> titled "The Awakening".
In 2007 Devgn starred in two movies, director <a href="Anubhav%20Sinha">Anubhav Sinha</a>'s action thriller "<a href="Cash%20%282007%20film%29">Cash</a>" and "<a href="Ram%20Gopal%20Varma%20Ki%20Aag">Ram Gopal Varma Ki Aag</a>".
In 2008, Devgn performed in the <a href="social%20film">social film</a> "<a href="Halla%20Bol">Halla Bol</a>", directed by <a href="Rajkumar%20Santoshi">Rajkumar Santoshi</a>. Also in the cast were <a href="Pankaj%20Kapoor">Pankaj Kapoor</a> and <a href="Vidya%20Balan">Vidya Balan</a>. The film is based on the life of activist <a href="Safdar%20Hashmi">Safdar Hashmi</a>, who was killed in 1989 by political rivals while performing in the street play "Halla Bol". The film received harsh reviews.
In 2008, Devgn also performed in <a href="Rohit%20Shetty">Rohit Shetty</a>'s third film "<a href="Sunday%20%282008%20film%29">Sunday</a>".
He then took the lead role with Kajol in his own directorial debut film "<a href="U%20Me%20Aur%20Hum">U Me Aur Hum</a>". The film performed moderately well at the box office and earned positive critical reviews for his performance as well as for his direction. Rediff said: "His character grows, discovers both shirt-buttons and subtlety, delivering an intense acting job. Speaking almost entirely in platitudes – pithy at first, profound as he goes on – this grows into an extraordinarily well-written character, replete with flaws and relatability. The way he treats his remorse, drunkenly pointing every finger at himself around a dinner table, is superbly handled, as is his guilty struggle to delineate his life experience from his professional opinion." Devgn also made a cameo appearance in his brother <a href="Anil%20Devgan">Anil Devgan</a>'s film "<a href="Haal%E2%80%93e%E2%80%93dil">Haal–e–dil</a>". He then starred in <a href="Afzal%20Khan%20%28actor%29">Afzal Khan</a>'s "<a href="Mehbooba%20%282008%20film%29">Mehbooba</a>".
Again in 2008, Devgn performed in <a href="Rohit%20Shetty">Rohit Shetty</a>'s comedy "<a href="Golmaal%20Returns">Golmaal Returns</a>", a sequel to the 2006 film "" about a mistrustful wife who believed her husband was unfaithful. "<a href="The%20Indian%20Express">The Indian Express</a>" said the screenplay was derivative, concluding: "There is nothing particularly new about a suspicious wife keeping tabs on her husband, and there is nothing particularly new in the way Ajay-Kareena play it." "Golmaal Returns" was a financial success with global revenues of .

The film was not popular with the public.
Commercial success (2010–present).
In the following decade, Devgn performed roles in "<a href="Once%20Upon%20a%20Time%20in%20Mumbaai">Once Upon a Time in Mumbaai</a>" (2010), "<a href="Golmaal%203">Golmaal 3</a>" (2010), "<a href="Raajneeti">Raajneeti</a>" (2010), "<a href="Singham">Singham</a>" (2011), "<a href="Bol%20Bachchan">Bol Bachchan</a>" (2012), "<a href="Son%20of%20Sardaar">Son of Sardaar</a>" (2012), "<a href="Singham%20Returns">Singham Returns</a>" (2014) and "<a href="Drishyam%20%282015%20film%29">Drishyam</a>" (2015).
In 2010, Devgn featured in the financially successful comedy "<a href="Atithi%20Tum%20Kab%20Jaoge%3F">Atithi Tum Kab Jaoge?</a>" with <a href="Paresh%20Rawal">Paresh Rawal</a> and <a href="Konkona%20Sen%20Sharma">Konkona Sen Sharma</a>. He then featured in <a href="Prakash%20Jha">Prakash Jha</a>'s political thriller "<a href="Raajneeti">Raajneeti</a>". "Raajneeti" was released internationally on 4 June 2010, after some controversies regarding similarities between actual people and the characters in the film. There were also issues about the use of the national anthem in the film. The film was made with a budget of When the film was released, it had positive reviews and was financially successful.
Again, in 2010, Devgn starred in <a href="Milan%20Luthria">Milan Luthria</a>'s "<a href="Once%20Upon%20a%20Time%20in%20Mumbaai">Once Upon a Time in Mumbaai</a>", which was among the top-grossing films of that year. Both the film and Devgn's performance were well received by the critics. <a href="Taran%20Adarsh">Taran Adarsh</a> said: "Ajay Devgn is splendid as Sultan. The actor had enacted a similar role in "Company", but it must be said that his interpretation is so different in "Once Upon A Time in Mumbaai". He adds so much depth to the character, which only goes to prove his range and versatility. This is, without a trace of doubt, Ajay's finest work so far." <a href="Komal%20Nahta">Komal Nahta</a> said: "Ajay Devgn is simply fantastic in the role of Sultan Mirza. So real is his performance that it looks like he was born to play this role. Right from his look to his acting including dialogue-delivery, everything is fabulous. Indeed, an award-winning performance!"
Devgn then starred in <a href="Priyadarshan">Priyadarshan</a>'s action-thriller film "<a href="Aakrosh%20%282010%20film%29">Aakrosh</a>". The movie explores the subject of <a href="honour%20killings">honour killings</a>. "<a href="Aakrosh%20%282010%20film%29">Aakrosh</a>" received some positive reviews, but was financially unsuccessful. At the end of 2010, Devgn worked again with Rohit Shetty in <a href="Golmaal%203">Golmaal 3</a>, a sequel to "Golmaal Returns" (2008). Although, like its predecessor, the film received mixed reviews, it was the most successful of the "Golmaal" series, earning more than . Devgn also worked as a voice artist in "<a href="Toonpur%20Ka%20Super%20Hero">Toonpur Ka Super Hero</a>", an animated film.
In 2011, Devgn performed with <a href="Emraan%20Hashmi">Emraan Hashmi</a> in <a href="Madhur%20Bhandarkar">Madhur Bhandarkar</a>'s comedy "<a href="Dil%20Toh%20Baccha%20Hai%20Ji">Dil Toh Baccha Hai Ji</a>". He was a narrator in "<a href="Yamla%20Pagla%20Deewana">Yamla Pagla Deewana</a>" and also made a cameo appearance in "<a href="Ready%20%282011%20film%29">Ready</a>". Devgn starred in Rohit Shetty's "<a href="Singham">Singham</a>". Taran Adarsh said: "The title means 'Lion' and Ajay is in the centre of the battle between good and evil. Ajay is well known for the lines, "aataa maajhi satakli". The embodiment of screen masculinity, Ajay enacts the central character of a righteous, hardhearted cop with flourish. He brings alive on screen a larger-than-life hero character with determined conviction, which renders you thunderstruck. One of the few actors who underplays his part admirably, he returns to the over-the-top-action genre of films with this one. In a nutshell, his performance plays a pivotal role in carrying the film to the winning post." He then starred <a href="David%20Dhawan">David Dhawan</a>'s <a href="action%20comedy%20film">action comedy film</a> "<a href="Rascals%20%282011%20film%29">Rascals</a>".
The following year, Devgn starred in "<a href="Tezz">Tezz</a>", directed by <a href="Priyadarshan">Priyadarshan</a>. His co-stars were <a href="Anil%20Kapoor">Anil Kapoor</a>, <a href="Boman%20Irani">Boman Irani</a>, <a href="Kangana%20Ranaut">Kangana Ranaut</a>, <a href="Sameera%20Reddy">Sameera Reddy</a> and <a href="Zayed%20Khan">Zayed Khan</a>. Devgan then starred in Rohit Shetty's film "<a href="Bol%20Bachchan">Bol Bachchan</a>". He then starred in "<a href="Son%20Of%20Sardaar">Son Of Sardaar</a>". The film received positive reviews, Meena Iyer of "<a href="The%20Times%20of%20India">The Times of India</a>" gave the film four out of five stars, describing it as "A suspense drama with a nail-biting finish." Production.
<a href="Ajay%20Devgn%20FFilms">Ajay Devgn FFilms</a> is an Indian film <a href="production%20company">production</a> and <a href="Film%20distributor">distribution</a> company established by actor Ajay Devgn in 2000. Based in <a href="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>, it mainly produces and distributes <a href="Hindi%20language">Hindi</a> films. In 2000, ADF released its first film, <a href="Raju%20Chacha">Raju Chacha</a>. The film starred Devgn himself as the lead actor and his wife <a href="Kajol">Kajol</a> as the lead actress. "Raju Chacha" received mixed reviews but grossed Rs 82.5 million at the box office.
In 2008, Devgn co-produced the drama "<a href="U%20Me%20Aur%20Hum">U Me Aur Hum</a>", which marked his directorial debut. Devgn also played the lead role in the film, sharing the screen again with Kajol. The film was written by Devgn himself and three other writers. Critical reception was generally positive, with <a href="Taran%20Adarsh">Taran Adarsh</a> giving the film 4 out of 5 stars and describing it as "A well-made, absorbing love story that's high on emotional quotient".
In 2009, Devgn released and acted in his home production "", which was directed by <a href="Rohit%20Shetty">Rohit Shetty</a> and also starring, <a href="Sanjay%20Dutt">Sanjay Dutt</a>, <a href="Fardeen%20Khan">Fardeen Khan</a>, <a href="Bipasha%20Basu">Bipasha Basu</a> and <a href="Mugdha%20Godse">Mugdha Godse</a>. The film was released on 16 October 2009 and received positive response from critics. It was rated a hit in India, and is the ninth <a href="Bollywood%20films%20of%202009">highest grossing Bollywood film of 2009</a>.
In 2014, ADF produced "<a href="Singham%20Returns">Singham Returns</a>" starring Devgn and <a href="Kareena%20Kapoor">Kareena Kapoor</a>. In 2016 Devgn produced and starred in "<a href="Shivaay">Shivaay</a>" which is to be the most expensive film of his production.
In late December 2017, ADF collaborated with <a href="Fox%20Star%20Studios">Fox Star Studios</a> to produce "<a href="Total%20Dhamaal">Total Dhamaal</a>" starring Devgn, <a href="Riteish%20Deshmukh">Riteish Deshmukh</a>, <a href="Arshad%20Warsi">Arshad Warsi</a>, <a href="Javed%20Jaffrey">Javed Jaffrey</a>, <a href="Madhuri%20Dixit">Madhuri Dixit</a>, and <a href="Anil%20Kapoor">Anil Kapoor</a>.
NY VFXWAALA.
In October 2015, Devgn established a <a href="visual%20effects">visual effects</a> company, NY VFXWAALA, after his children. It has been involved with many major films, such as "<a href="Prem%20Ratan%20Dhan%20Payo">Prem Ratan Dhan Payo</a>", "<a href="Tamasha%20%282015%20film%29">Tamasha</a>", "<a href="Bajirao%20Mastani">Bajirao Mastani</a>", "<a href="Mersal%20%28film%29">Mersal</a>", "<a href="Dilwale%20%282015%20film%29">Dilwale</a>", "<a href="Force%202">Force 2</a>", and "<a href="Simmba">Simmba</a>". The company won the <a href="National%20Film%20Award%20for%20Best%20Special%20Effects">Best Special Effects</a> award at the <a href="64th%20National%20Film%20Awards">64th National Film Awards</a> for the film "<a href="Shivaay">Shivaay</a>" (2016).
